items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely today, Friday 10th December and into tomorrow. Water levels have dropped, but remain responsive to rainfall and tide locking.  This is due to a natural tide locking effect combined with the overnight rainfall. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning.   Further rain is expected tomorrow afternoon and into the evening which could lead to river levels once again rising. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Saturday 11th December.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Whilst river and lake levels have now peaked and are receding, river levels on the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water still remain high. Flooding is likely to affect low lying areas near the Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water. Avoid using low lying footpaths, particularly around the lake edge and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. We continue to monitor the situation and this message will be updated tomorrow, Saturday 11/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Flint Mill and Basford Bridge river gauges following rainfall associated with Storm Barra.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Churnet between Leek and Rocester and the River Tean between Adderley and Spath including Cecilly Brook at Cheadle.   
Further light rainfall is expected during Friday, so we expect levels to drop below alert levels. However, rainfall is expected over the coming days so further alerts are likely over the weekend and into Monday.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast..  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 11/12/21, or as the situation changes.

This flood alert has been removed as river levels are now falling below levels of concern and there is no significant rainfall forecast over the weekend. Please take care when out and about as there may still be standing water in low lying areas near local watercourses.

River levels are high but remain steady at the Ross on Wye gauge as a result of Storm Barra. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today 10/12/21. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations that may be affected include the A438, Byford, Bredwardine and Hereford. Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye peaked at 2.98m, Bredwardine peaked at 5.12m, Belmont peaked at 5.03m, Old Wye Bridge peaked at 4.52m, Mordiford peaked at 4.54m, Ross-on-wye peaked 3.93m. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high into the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 11/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further light rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message: River levels are falling at the Leintwardine river gauge as a result of Storm Barra. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Teme, River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include Bishops Castle, Church Stretton, Knighton and Ludlow. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are liaising with emergency services. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 9am on 11/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are steady at the Ross-On-Wye river gauge as a result of Storm Barra. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today 10/12/21. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye. Ross-on-wye peaked at 3.93m Friday morning 10/12/2021. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high into the weekend. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 11/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding at the present time, though standing water and debris may still remain.  The forecast for the next 24 hours is for largely clear spells and mainly dry, with an occasional shower. The catchments remain wet and we continue to monitor the situation.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

River levels have risen at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of Storm Barra. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 10/12/21. We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to rise and remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 10am on 11/12/21, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Great Bridgford river gauge following rainfall associated with Storm Barra.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 3 days and we expect river levels to remain high over the weekend and into Monday.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast..  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 11/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Avon River Swift and Clay Coton Brook
items.message: River levels are currently high at the Lilbourne river gauge, in response to the rainfall yesterday (09/12/2021) evening.  Consequently, the flooding of roads and farmland is possible today (10/12/2021).  Flooding could affect low-lying land and roads adjacent to River Avon between Stanford and Rugby, River Swift between Cosford and Rugby and Clay Coton Brook between Yelvertoft and Lilbourne. There is little further rainfall forecast until midday on Saturday (12/12/2021).  We therefore expect the river levels to begin falling.  However, we then expect the river levels to rise again over night on Saturday in response to this new rainfall, therefore it is likely this Flood Alert will remain in force for the next few days.  We are closely monitoring the situation and actively checking river levels and the weather forecasts. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and bridges near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 11/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels have started to rise again at the Pillings Lock river gauge as a result of the rain overnight.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Slash Lane at Sileby and the Mountsorrel to Sileby road.   
Further rainfall is forecast over Saturday afternoon, 11/12/21.  We expect river levels to remain high until 11/12/21.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 11/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Willington Cableway and Shardlow river gauges as a result of recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Areas most at risk are low-lying agricultural land and roads including Willington, Barrow upon Trent, Swarkestone, Bargate Lane and the access roads to Willington Meadows, the Twyford Village access road, Church Lane at Barrow, and Ingleby Lane. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 11/12/2021, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley.
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  River levels at Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Cae Howel are falling, but still pose a flood risk.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning 11/12/21 by 09:00, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

floodArea.county: Cheshire West and Chester, Flintshire, Shropshire, Wrexham

items.message: River levels have risen on the River Dee due to heavy rainfall, but remain steady. Flooding is possible of low lying land and roads around the River Dee at Shocklach, Farndon, Handley, Lower Kinnerton, Chester and Puddington. Townfield Lane remains cut off. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation. This message will be updated by 4pm on Saturday 11th December, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible overnight tonight, 10/12/21.  Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore.
Predicted peaks:- Mythe 3.7 to 4.2m on Tuesday 14/12/21, Haw Bridge 4.7 to 5.2m on Tuesday 14/12/21, Sandhurst 3.5 to 4m on Tuesday 14/12/21, Gloucester 2.7 to 3.2m on Tuesday 14/12/21.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 11/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels remain high but are beginning to fall at the Marston on Dove river gauge following rainfall associated with Storm Barra.  Consequently, the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Dove between Rocester and Clay Mills.   
Further light rainfall is expected during Friday, but we expect levels to drop below alert levels. However, more rainfall is expected over the coming days so further alerts are likely over the weekend and into Monday.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 11/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Buildwas river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. Floodplain at Leighton starts to fill. Crew Green peaked on Thursday, Montford peaked Friday morning, Welshbridge predicted peak 3.4m to 3.7m Friday evening, Buildwas predicted peak 4.7m to 5m Saturday afternoon, Bridgnorth 3.7m to 4.2m Saturday afternoon.   
Further heavy rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated  tomorrow morning 11/12/21 by 09:00, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal River Waveney from Ellingham to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this evening, Friday 10 December and overnight. Water levels are expected to rise gradually through this afternoon and overnight. This is due to a natural tide locking effect over the next two tides. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, will restrict the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels at Beccles Quay.  Levels should peak at around 6am tomorrow morning and begin to drop as this period of tide locking passes. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Saturday 11 December.

items.description: The tidal River Yare from Thorpe St Andrew to Breydon Water
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely this evening, Friday 10 December and overnight. Water levels are expected to rise gradually through this afternoon and overnight. This is due to a natural tide locking effect over the next two tides. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, will restrict the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels in Brundall and Reedham riverside areas.  Levels should peak in the morning and begin to drop as this period of tide locking passes. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Saturday 11 December.

items.description: The River Bure, Spixworth Beck and surrounding Becks
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely.  River levels are still higher than normal and will remain responsive to further rainfall. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas between Horsford and Crostwick on the Spixworth Beck, and Corpusty, Saxthorpe, Itteringham, Ingworth, Aylsham and Burgh-next-Aylsham on the Bure.  The forecast is for continued unsettled weather over the next couple of days. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 11am tomorrow, Saturday 11th December 2021.

River levels continue to rise at the Stapleford river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of property/roads and farmland is possible today, Friday 10 December. We expect flooding to affect the River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach.   

No further rainfall is forecast tonight but further rainfall is forecast tomorrow afternoon and evening, Saturday 11 December.  We expect river levels to remain high tonight.

We are closely monitoring the situation.   

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, Saturday 11 December, or as the situation changes.

River levels are rising at the Bewdley river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible from overnight tonight, 10/12/2021.  Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations that may be affected include Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and the Hylton Road towpath. Flooding from drains may also be affecting the racecourse and the Worcester County cricket ground.
Predicted peaks:- Bewdley 3.7 to 4.2m on Saturday night 11/12/21, Worcester 4.5 to 5m on Sunday afternoon 12/12/21, Diglis 4 to 4.5m on Sunday afternoon 12/12/21, Kempsey Yacht Club 6 to 6.5m on Sunday night 12/12/21.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 11/12/21, or as the situation changes.

Flooding may affect low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. We expect to begin operating Kempsey Flood Alleviation scheme from Saturday afternoon, 11/12/21. Predicted peak:- Kempsey Yacht Club 6 to 6.5m on Sunday night, 12/12/21.   
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 9am on Saturday 11/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

We are closely monitoring the situation.  

Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.
